header.postText: Top 10 Celebs Who Shut Down Sexist Interview Questions // Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/MsMojo?sub_c... Anne Hathaway, Tom Hardy, Keira Knightley, Lauren Conrad, Emma Stone, Scarlett Johansson, Rowan Blanchard, Ariana Grande, Serena Williams, Rihanna and Jennifer Lawrence have been asked some pretty sexist questions before, but they were quick to shut it down! commentThread.commentText: Did anyone else get an ad for makeup right when Ariana was asked about things girls prefer? Because I did.
Is the guy who asked Scarlett Johansen about her underwear the same person you asked Anne Hathaway about her fitness routine.

It's not the questions themselves that's the issue. It's the fact that members of the press ask different questions to males and females. Females, with their sexualized bodies, get asked about things regarding their appearances. Males get asked about deeper things.
I can see where the dislikes come from, and it gives me joy. 😂

Daniel Craig is another great example. An interviewer was asking all these questions about the "Bond girls" and referred to Monica Bellucci as playing an older sexual conquest. He replied with, "you mean someone MY age?" The "catsuit" question that still comes up so often was lampshaded even back in the era of Galaxy Quest where Sigourney Weaver's character complains that TV Guide asked the men character questions while her segment was "all about my boobs and how they fit in my costume!"
So I guess only white women stand up for themselves? Lol

The Avengers cast basically couldn't say anything, but had been booked for interviews everywhere. Exercise routines were gruelling for the whole cast, and it isn't a bad question.


To ask someone who uses instagram on her phone to publish photos of herself with makeup which she'd rather keep, is also a very reasonable question. Sure, she might not want to answer in which case you should probably stop asking, but I've seen interviewers ask people to choose between two even more mundane things.

Here's my idea about looks in tv and film. It's known that women have a FAR greater expectation to conform to beauty standards than men if they want to get cast. AND show business execs don't exactly TRY to get away from that stereotype when casting actors (they fear losing money). Therefore the number of female actors who are considered good looking outnumbers how many male actors who are considered good looking. I'm thinking that this affects the statistics for the interview questions. When a male actor is conventionally hot, they get these questions too. What's your work out regiment? What do you eat? Do you wake up looking this good? I mean those questions are still totally disproportionately skewed towards women, but it's not inherently sexist to ask about physical appearance. Men are lusted after too....  However, if a interviewer is only asking about looks, it's freaking obvious the interview is only about one thing. I'm not saying this is the sole reason for these types of questions are being more often posed to women, but I like to think about all contributing factors instead of jumping on bandwagons.

commentThread.commentText: To people doubting the sexism of the Serena Williams one: do you ever hear people ask - idk - Tom Brady how it feels to be the best male athlete? The name of the athlete doesn't matter - look at most male athletes and the praise they get. It's never made as blatantly clear that they are male and by constantly putting 'female' before awards that women get, it suggests that they and their accomplishments aren't comparable to a mans. It doesn't just apply to sports. Take comedy, for example. When a male comic is interviewed/awarded/spoken of in general, people feel no need to explicitly state the fact that they are male. Female comic on the other hand? It's constantly mentioned that they are female, and they are constantly bombarded with stupid questions about 'how it feels to be a female comic'. It implies that female comedians are unnatural; that male comedians are the default and the norm. B.S. On that last point, you should look up Amy Poehler and Tina Fey because they've discussed how stupid, demeaning and annoying this is for women. They did one interview with E! where the guy asked about their gender in relation to their job and the pair's reaction was priceless. (Also, maybe guys do get asked about their workout regimen, but nowhere near as much. And not on a panel with all their costars - the ScarJo one was degrading for her because she was with a bunch of other castmates that day and whilst they got asked about storylines/acting, all the press wanted to pry from her were beauty tips. Again, diminishing B.S.)

It's sexist when done towards women because there is an inherent bias women as a group experience in society that leads to those questions being SPECIFICALLY aimed at women. Our culture inherently sees women as sex objects (where bodies are valued, more than intelligence) while men as a group have never been seen as objects, as the male sex. Men's status as human beings is/has always been seen as the creator/leader/jack of all trades (men are the leaders of the culture, and it has been structured to serve men), which means they can be seen a s sexual, physically attractive AND capable of being human and at the forefront of society, while women have not been granted the same privilege. The personhood of the ma le sex has never been a question. For wom en, sexual objectification is literal, whereas men have been socially taught (and constantly reaffirmed by the media, politics, and every other societal institution) that women aren't equal, but rather secondary tools that can be used and exploited and here for their advantage. That is why those comments are sexist towards women. It is not sexist towards men, ever. That's not what sexism is or how it functions in society.

Nine out of ten are indeed incorrect. These reporters asked unfair and sexist questions. Hats off for the witty answers! Number ten, the Serena Williams one on the other hand is off the rails. She played against women exclusively, and had all those great results in competitions where men were excluded from. Take a hint from chess: there are open tournaments, which means anybody (men and women alike) can attend. When a woman wins such a tournament, she will be called the best player of the event (not the best female player). E.g., Judit Polgár or Hou Yifan were/are regularly invited to top open tournaments, because they were/are among the best chess players in the world. The world champion is Magnus Carlsen, because he won the series for the OPEN title. He is not the man world champion, he is the world champion. There is no such thing as man world champion, and nobody calls Magnus Carlsen the best male chess player. There is however a title called "woman world champion". I don't care who t he woman world champion is, because that title is meaningless, and in my opinion, offensive to women. Hou Yifan expressed the same opinion when she rejected to fight for that title. If Serena Williams is offended to be called one of the best female athletes of all time, then she should take a leaf out of Judit Polgár's and Hou Yifan's book, and compete against all tennis players, regardless of th eir gender. Until then: the question was justified.

I agree these are lame questions. But, there's some that (to be fair) are only considered sexist if asked to a woman. The underwear one, for example, I've seen asked to every actor that has played Spider-man. I also remember Ioan Gruffudd having to uncomfortably talk about the size of his dick while in his Fantastic 4 costume, yet no one bats an eye because he's a man. It's an incredibly stupid question, but not restrictive to women. Same goes for diet and exercise, which I've seen asked to Henry Cavill, Hugh Jackman, Chris Pratt, etc. Also, consider what articles you click before damming every interviewer as an idiot. If you chose a headline telling you how to get in Scarlet Johanson's shape ove r Black Widow's character development, remember you are also determining the type of questions she'll be asked in the future. These journalists have a job too, and as amazing as it might be to write about the complexities of a character, if their article gets no clicks, they'll be forced to ask shallow questions.

commentThread.commentText: In 1998 Serena Williams and her sister was beaten by a man, Karsten Braasch (ranked 203). She does not compete against men on normal circumstance and (to my knowledge) hasn't since. "Athlete" is genderless (a person who is proficient in sports and other forms of physical exercise). So when comparing Athletes, we need to compare their proficiency to all other Athletes. If she can obtain those achievements compared to others regardless of gender then she would be considered "One of the greatest" of that word (Athlete). Since she does not compete against a certain form of those Athletes (males), that claim will have and asterisk (*), which would stand for "female". So considering that, how is it sexist to ask what it's like to be one of the greatest female athletes? Looking for an actual answer here, I'm willing to retract my comment if a logical answer is found. (note: Since she only set those records while playing against the aforementioned "*", I consider them impressive, but not relevant to this question)

CoolCat Well, it's about what interviewers focus on, what they think is the most important or most significant to ask at that moment. It's a shallow question that could be thrown at for example Tom Hardy, but most dudes are taken too seriously to even get that kind of questions. If he says "can we talk about my role instead? The reporter would likely say "oh yeah of course, I guess there are moee important things to focus on". If it's a girl saying "hey let's not focus on that right now", they will often try again and again to get their question answered because some feel like they can't take a no as an answer from a woman. For a lot of these, context is key. Hardly any (well, aside from the underwear one and Helen Mirren's) are obviously sexist, but because these questions are largely pointed at women, and only women, and because when women try to answer shortly and/or change the subject the interviewer will just ask again and more insistingly, that makes those questions sexist. So no, if you ask one of your girl friends about her fitness routine, that's not sexist. If you insist on asking even when she's not interested in telling you, that's being an asshole. If you insist on asking her but you would accept a "Oi, dude, please stop this line of questioning already" from a man, then it's sexist. If you ask a girl friend about her make up or cell phone, it's not sexist. If you insist that that's the only interests she could possibly have because she's a woman? Yeah. Wonder of wonder, that's sexist. I mean, it's not rocket science, this?

Guadalupe Rodriguez isn't a tennis more on skill than muscle.

No, the problem is that working on skill will only take you so far, at all levels of the game, you will find barriers to improvement due to fitness and physical strength. At the top end of tennis, it takes a huge amount of physical strength to hit a ball over the net at 110mph with enough top spin to keep it in the court. Even if you have trained enough to hit the lines every time, you aren't going to be able to maintain that when someone is belting it back at you at such pace, without comparable strength. This is why serving is so important, it is very difficult to return a 140mph serve with any kind of precision and control, most tennis players primary concern when facing serves of that speed is simply to get it back in the court. I played competitively as a teenager and had a 115mph first serve, and less than half the time would it make it back over the net, simply because the physical strength necessary to return such a serve just isn't there in most teenage tennis players, and this is something that remains true right the way throughout the game, it has served players like Karlovic, Isner and Roddick well.

replies.commentText: Today there is a big disconnect between what people think of feminism and equality. I'm sorry because I can't remember the exact numbers but there was a poll asking people if they believed in gender equality. As expected the answers were almost 100% yes. They then asked the same people if they were feminists. The number of people who said yes dropped drastically. This shows that because of the actions of many 'feminists' a large portion of people no longer view feminism as a fight for equality. And I also don't think that women 'repopulate the earth' on their own lol. Men might just play a role in that too.

Corey,  I'm going to suggest that it's not "...the actions of many 'feminists'", but what people perceive those actions to be, partially due to their own bias, rumour, misunderstanding, and the basic drive of being a group of stupid, reactionary herd animals.  I'll address the last one first.  Have you ever noticed the vitriol whistleblowers face, even when it's exposing a threat to the safety and welfare of the general public?  Why do we as a group respond in such a manner?  Logic would dictate that we would be grateful to the whistleblower, but we aren't.  I think this is so because we wrongly perceive power to be safety, so when someone "rocks the boat" , so to speak, we see that as the threat, not the exposure of corruption, etc. on the part of those in power.  As for misunderstanding, it is often fed by quotes.  For example, a friend called me in a flap because her son showed her a quote from a feminist saying that all sex is rape.  She tried to use this against me, citing that this is the shit people like me foist upon others.  After a 20 second Google search, I found the author of the quote (name escapes me).  The quote was taken out of context from a 20 MINUTE presentation (which took place in the early 90s) on challenging the concept that consent is concrete.  She, a law professor at a well-respected university, stated that a person's background and experiences will alter what is and isn't acceptable to the individual (a person who experienced varying degrees of sexual assault during formative years is likely to accept more denigrating behaviours than someone raised in a supportive home that cultured personal autonomy).  Then there's our attraction, as a culture, to looking to the most outlandish examples, no matter how rare, to support our viewpoints - primarily because we equate being wrong with being bad.  We will avoid being wrong at all costs, and I think that's why there's the misconception of feminism -- because many of these people point out some of the wrongs of our society.  Then, as a deflection, we trip over ourselves to point out what is wrong with them because we fear for the safety of the unit, even though the unit itself is flawed and sick.

You really need to rethink your attitude towards gender specific questions like these, if you can't spot the sexism in most of them.

I'm probably not the best person to try to explain why they are sexist, but let's give it a go. Firstly, it's sexist not only to women, but to men in celebrity culture too, that they are asked specific questions the other gender may not be asked. It's arguably worse for women, who tend to get asked questions like ‘how do you balance your work and personal life' - like women can't handle having a relationship and children whilst working. That question also assumes that the mother is the primary carer of the child, whereas the partner is more often than not responsible for half the care. Secondly, questions about underwear:hair colour/ diet advice are irrelevant to the job these ladies (and men!! Who get asked about work out routines too) are doing. These people are WORKING, the interview is a job, part of the promotional process for their product. They're being professional, and the interviewer is askin about personal things, which is inappropriate. Also asking about diet tips further adds to a culture where in women should all be worried about how they look, and unfortunately adds to a culture where in men feel as though they need to bulk up. This not only helps in causing eating disorders, but imagine constantly being probed about your weight - these celebrities must feel like shit all the time. (And no, just because they're famous doesn't mean it ‘comes with the job', and No, just because they're rich doesn't mean they should just forget about it) There is LOADS more I can say on this topic, and I don't want to sound preachy but I do hope you read through and some of what I said makes sense to you, even if you don't agree with it all.

Well we've been on this page a few weeks longer than your pathetic attempt at snark.  I am real damn familiar with the way both YouTube and Mojo works, and there are some things I don't like.  If no one talks about the shit we don't like, it will never change, will it?  So why don't you take your "witty remarks" somewhere else, jackass.
Amen
You can't just make a video using entirely someone else's content, that's definitely copyright infringement

Sam Lemke actually, you technically can. copyright infringement has next to nothing to do with the amount of footage used and more to do with the intent of the use. If they are using it just to redistribute that clip for profit, it's copyright infringement. however, top 10 lists like this actually fall under the category of fair use, as it is being used to be commented upon (even if nothing is actually said).
madeleine61509 That's completely wrong. You're talking about the review aspect of fair use. If they don't say anything about it then that's not a review and therefore not fair use

No, rating things (as top 10s do) also counts as a form of review/comment. That is especially the case when they only include snippets of the clips (as they do in this) and they include the source for the clip (as they do in this).

You'd be surprised how broad fair use actually is when you read into it. It's just that original owners want to make as much money as possible and thus will threaten any person who uses their footage (sometimes even when that footage is undeniably used within fair use). plus, when faced with the possibility of a lawsuit for copyright infringement, most people will just back down and agree to the person's commands rather than actually fighting against it.

madeleine61509 I don't mean to sound patronising but you clearly do not understand fair use at all. The content of the video is what matters, not the title. Going by your logic, you could upload an entire film to YouTube, with no commentary, and claim that you're ranking it as every scene is better than the last. Obviously that isn't true at all. Sorry but you're completely wrong.

No, it has to do with two things: 1) intent and 2) whether or not it has the potential to act as a "replacement" for the original media.

So, in terms of point #1: If you uploaded the entire movie unedited and in order, it's very unlikely that comment/criticism/parody is your actual intention. That's why videos like that are usually taken down. The concept of watch/ms mojo's videos is rating things. they use short clips of the content which are either from completely different pieces of content (such as this video) or are clips from completely different moments in the same piece of media (i.e. "best moments from x tv show"). Someone can (hypothetically) upload the majority of the footage of a movie/song/TV episode if there is reason to believe that their intent is criticism/comment/parody.

And in terms of point #2: Watch/Ms Mojo's videos (even without their commentary) are not in any way a replacement for the original pieces of media that it talks about. Uploading an entire movie unedited is absolutely a replacement for seeing the movie in the cinema or buying a hardcopy, thus it is copyright infringement. To use the top video in the recommended bar right now as an example: "Top 10 Friends jokes that would NOT work on TV today".  The 8-9 minute video on one very specific aspect of the show is nowhere near a replacement for the 121 hours of content of Friends. In this video, showing a single answer (or even sometimes just half of an answer) is not a replacement for the original footage of the interviews.

This is clearly the hypothetical. YouTube in particular is absolute BS nowadays. They will demonetize/mute/take down your video for 3 seconds of copyrighted music and people are being sued over videos which are undeniably fair use cough H3H3 cough , but I'm talking about what the law actually says.

madeleine61509 The amount of content you use is completely irrelevant, it still belongs to someone else. Think of it in terms of a material possession, whether you steal $10 or $30, it's still theft. If you do not provide commentary, satire or any other things that fall under fair use then it's infringement. Simple as that.

Theft is clearly not relevant here. It doesn't suddenly stop being theft if you then comment on how wrinkled or pristine the $10 bill is. If you're going to come up with an analogy, at least make it work with the rules you yourself are trying to put forward. I think you just don't understand how fair use works because of how much YouTube has absolutely shat on it lately.

Fact is, rating is covered under fair use, especially when the content that is used does not act as a replacement for the original piece of media.Commentary is another form of criticism, etc. covered under fair use, but it isn't the only one. Once again, if you actually bothered reading the laws surrounding copyright and fair use, you'd be surprised just how broad it is. It's just that media companies are getting incredibly greedy and are suing/issuing copyright claims against anything which is to do with their content (especially if it is negative) just so they can get a few extra bucks.

madeleine61509 Okay, I'm done. Theft is relevant because intellectual property, just like money or a nice set of speakers, belongs to someone or a corporation. If you don't know that, then you clearly are absolutely clueless about copyright. I am honestly amazed that you would even think about talking about something you have so little understanding on.

Then tell me how the criticism (fair use) comes into play in your analogy... because you're saying that taking video is perfectly fine as long as there is commentary about it as well (which I am not arguing against, it's just that clearly makes this analogy irrelevant) but I don't see how talking about the quality of the money you have stolen suddenly makes it ok. Rating counts as a form of commentary (which by the way is not just about talking over something. It is any form of expressing an opinion)...

So, how does fair use (commentary, criticism, satire) fit into your theft analogy? Because if it doesn't, then how can you honestly say it's relevant in a  discussion about fair use? If anything, it feels like you're trying to say that fair use doesn't exist and commentary on a video is still copyright infringement. That's what that analogy suggests.

I don't think you have any clue of what you're talking about and you're just saying whatever you can in order to try and cover up your lack of education on this topic. Candice Nicole - For starters you should know I recognize the good feminists. My own sister was a feminist for years and she did not have toxic ideas. If you look at the most popular feminist movements, in general, feminists have very toxic ideas. For example I listed several below. Wage Gap - (Fallacy) According to the US Department of Labor (feel free to look this up) men work on average at least 4 more hours than women do every week. 52 weeks in a year makes at least 208 more hours on average. If men are working over 200 hours than woman a year, then of course the medians will be higher. The idea that men are paid more for the same job is a false extrapolation from a statistical median in a distribution of data points. Free The Nipple Movement - (Vulgarity and Hypocrisy) I cannot think of a more useless movement if I can be honest. Patriarchy - (Imaginary) Women have higher IQ's and grades then men on average. Women have better access to college grants/scholarships, healthcare, and government aid simply because they are a woman. I do not see evidence of this mythical group trying to hold women back. If anything men have historically been told to sacrifice their time, finances, and even lives for women w ith nothing in return. I see more evidence of a "Matriarchy" haha. Rape Culture - (Toxicity) Feminists will say that we live in a rape culture because some men have raped and got away with it. By that same logic we must also live in a murder culture, thief culture, and littering culture. Do these cultures exist? Are there some men out there who want to rape? Yes of course, but to call a whole country a rape culture based on these rare accounts is simply inaccurate. This country is not "pro rape", I have never met someone in my life who thought rape was a good idea. Our laws are against rape and rapists, especially child rapists, go to prison for a long time as they should. Yes the court system makes mistakes, but those minorities do not stand for the 300+ million people who live in the U.S. We do not live in a rape culture for the same reason who do not live in a murder culture, and telling young men that they are all potential rapists is deplorable and shows the toxicity and bias of feminism against men. These are just 4 myths and toxic ideas that are associated with feminism. Based on these ideas, you can define modern feminist ideas to be, in general, toxic. Thank you for reading.

Joshua Fyfe Well, it's good you're a believer in the statistics. However, what you've (sort of) cited doesn't dismiss the wage gap problem, it kinda reinforces it. Average work hours actually only differs by 0.4 hours per day which amounts to only 2 hours per week. That means women work on average 95% than that of men, but still only earn 79% the wage... Obviously that's still leaves a 16% gap (depending, of course, on your ethnicity.) However, this hourly average only refers to only paid additional hours... so it's not exactly the most reliable as this could go either way: either women don't work longer hours, or they do but just don't get paid the extra hours. Studies have shown that women actually work on average 50 minutes more per day than men in unpaid workplace labour. So, if men work 24 minutes more per day in paid labour, then women are still working an additional 26 minutes more than men per day - meaning women work 4% more than men. Also, higher paying jobs tend to have longer hours - so, if women arn't being hired to higher paying jobs, then of course they arn't racking up the additional 24 minutes of paid labor each day - and, given that women in the West tend to hold more degrees than men, it begs the question why men continue to get the higher paying jobs? You'll never convince me discrimination against women in the workplace (which leads to the pay gap) doesn't exists - because not only is it statistically supported, I've seen it over and over and over again. A supervisory position came up in an office, containing 38 women and 1 man (minus the existing manager). 14 women candidates with post-secondary education, 5 to 30 years of experience, and most regularly worked after hours (unpaid) applied. The 1 man (my friend), who had only been employed for 8 months, didn't have a post-secondary education, and didn't stay a minute after finish time (not that he has to, it's his right) was the one who was hired. In another office, my colleague reported to our boss that she was pregnant, and his response was to tell her that she had "thrown her career out the window." During her maternity leave, they surplused her job, renamed it, denied her application and gave the "new" job to a man. She had a month to find a new job within the company and as a result took a $2000/week pay cut.  I don't even know how to respond to your offense to "Free the Nipple", other then to roll my eyes. 'Vulgar', really? I mean... you're just reaching for anything at this point.... Like, who cares of some women want to go topless just like men are allowed to go topless? This is your definition of toxic? Patriarchy isn't a mythical illuminati group, it's a social system which has been built upon since the dawn of time. I mean, I think we can all recognize that things were pretty shitty for women rights on paper up to the last century... Women couldn't vote until the 20s, you could legally be fired for getting pregnant before the 60s, couldn't get a credit card without a male co-signer until the 70s, it wasn't until the 90s that you were allowed to refus e sex with your husband... that's not that long ago. I'll back up... . 'patriarchy' is a social system established by men in predominate in roles of political and moral leadership.  On a basic level, we can look at the U.S. Congress.... The record high is 20% women.... In a country where 50% of the population is women. Even with that "record" high, Trump couldn't even pick a sin gle woman to join the 13-member group working on health care legislation. In terms of religious institutions... it's even worse. By definition tha t is patriarchy. So, of course the male perspective has dominated and shaped society - it's only logical. What is illogical is the belief that it somehow died over night - exactly what date do you be lieve patriarchy  was over? It's not a boogeyman, it's not men consciously (with some exceptions) trying to oppress women, it's a tradition that we have been raised with, which is why it is harder for some people to recognize it. Rape culture... I think I'm seeing a pattern of why you're getting it wrong. For one, you're defensive because you think feminism is an attack on men. Secondly, you can't seem to grasp the nuances. Third, the concept you do have of these terms is very superficial, and, for the most part, just wrong. Rape culture isn't about how many perpetrators are locked up... It's about the normalization of non-cons ensual sexual relationships, combined with historical patriarchal constructs, which lead to dangerous behaviour against women and yes, influences the justice system. Keep it in mind then next time you watch a movie or a TV shoe - it's very evident there in all the antics men use to "get the girl". Consider how these would play out in the real world, and consider what message was interpreted from it and how maybe it impacted your view of flirting... Then compare them to the reactions to assault allegations - there is a very clear line there. Regardless, I understand that "toxic" is the new favorite buzzword for anti-feminists, but, I still don't see anywhere you've shown how these concepts are toxic.... You just keep saying toxic... How?

Feminism is still not accepted, ever since women got the right to vote people think that feminism is no longer needed. But that's not true. I don't agree with the "feminazis" or any other feminist that hates men for whatever reason. I believe in social equality for both genders. And I'm not talking about the biological stuff, men and women ARE different on a biological note. Men have square fat cells while women have circular fat cells. Men tend to overheat because of their external equipment while women are externally cold because of our internal equipment. We are different and I think that's great! We're unique to each other♡. However, we should be socially equal because we are human. We're not different species, we are the same. Women are treated differently in the military than men and it's often sexist. I've had friends tell me that their 50 y r old mothers needed their uteruses removed but a male doctor kept it in so that they could have more children even though they are 50 and have had many children already. Which caused the mother to be in constant pain. I've met women whose husbands sent them to a psychiatric ward even though many psychologists confirmed that t he woman is in sound mind, she had just been abused by said husband. I want women to be made to go on the drafting lists like men are made to. I don't want my little brother to go to war. I wan t a woman president (not Hillary, fuck no)to be in office someday in my lifetime. I want men to not be stigmatized for protecting themselves against women assailants. I want equality for all. We still have a long way to go.

Hawkfeather I applaud your objective, rational stance on the true definition of the word "equality". However, I disagree that we "have a long way to go". For cultures other than the West, this is very true. But in Western culture, specifically the US, social differences in regard to gender have significantly narrowed. Single women in the largest cities in the US are, on average, earning higher salary than single men in the same cities. Does this differ when factoring in maternity leave/having children? Absolutely. But even when this is factored in, most of the differences can still be explained by reasonable causes. I've worked at 3 different enterprise-level businesses, and 2 out of the 3 offer paid maternity leave and have a general preference of hiring women over men for various positions. In my first position as a graduate, I was paid less than my female counterparts in the exact same role who only had roughly 6 or 8 months more in tenure than me, which I was perfectly fine with. After about a year and a half, however, I was able to do the job faster and more efficient, and successfully negotiated a pay raise because of that, which many women choose not to approach. Men will always be protective and caring over women, as it is in their biology. A growing number of women see this as appalling, when in reality it should be valued. That is how many animal species have survived and grown over the years. Men also enjoy being cared for by women, although some will never admit this. But for this same reason, many men do not want women to be forcibly drafted, because we are meant to protect them. Our survival as a species also depends upon the survival of women. As for the issue of male doctors and refusing to remove uteruses, this sounds like a very unique and uncommon case, but I would always urge for people to research both sides of a story. Have they sought second opinions from othe r doctors? Additionally, although it is possible for a spouse to send his or her partner to a psychiatric ward, there are several conditions that must be met, such as eye-witness testimony, and the person signing the petition would need to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the partner is in need of psychiatric assistance, so unless those women falsely admitted to their alleged behavior, and an independent psychiatrist documented it as being authentic, there's simply no way this would happen. There are far too many conditions that have to be met. Otherwise, people would send anyone they didn't like away to a psych ward for no reason.

I'm just gonna say I don't exactly agree with the whole sexism thing. *Before you chew me out*, I want to say that currently, sexism is directed at a certai n gender, specifically male s. Sexism happens to both sexes, male & female. Yes, it does happen to women much more often than men, so it's understandable if the wo rd 'sexism' just immediately reminds you of a guy who's at fault. However, it's WRONG to think that it just happens to one gender, and that it' s NOT sexism if the position is reversed. It's kind of the same situation with rape. If a guy raped a female, then he would be thrown behind bars, bu t if a woman did it, it might be shrugged off. I just don't like how some words are directed at a s pecific gender, like how feminists HAVE to be women. I am sure there are plenty of men out there who vouch and campaign for equal rights of BOTH genders, both male & female. The point that I'm really getting at is *equality*. If we all want equality, we have to stop pitting one against another. We have to *STOP GENERALIZING*. I know some people might describe me as "butthurt", but honestly, this is nothing about being butthurt. This is about society progressing forward with a better future in mind. Thanks for reading my rant.

Roxane Barker -- First of all, I commend you most sincerely for taking the time to check that out. I'm rather shocked that someone actually did :-) I found the film pretty balanced in its presentation (giving plenty of mic time to the "blue pill" faction), and thought it brave on the part the filmmaker to be willing to critically examine and reevaluate some of her deeply rooted beliefs, especially since doing so would likely get her excommunicated and excoriated by rabid feminists and other Progressives (as, indeed, it did). Also, I strongly suspect that the title wasn't simply a reference to the eponymous MRA movement, but rather that it was named after the much broader Red >Pill phenomenon -- the sort of counter-zeitgeist that's been growing in response to the cultural inroads made by Third-Wave Feminism, identity politics, globalism, and other branches of Postmodern Cultural Marxism. As for the particular MRA opinion you cited, I can understand why it might make you bristle a bit, but it does make some sense to me that eac h gender ( or sex, if you prefer) might be designed to play some vital role, to serve some crucial function for the other (beyond procreation, I mean). In short, we're meant to complement one another. Otherwise, what would be the point of a binary species? Why not have just evolved into a unary species that reproduces asexually (which, admittedly, would simplify things, but would also make existence a lot more boring)? And maybe that's where we're ultimately headed, but, in the meantime, we're stuck with each other, and it would be nice if we could achieve some kind of détente, or rapprochement...

Serena Williams in absolutely NOT one of the best athlete's ever. She is basically a man so has dominated femaile tennis which is a joke anyway. But here is a little known story;

How to... beat both Williams sisters in one afternoon

Karsten Braasch is the German tennis player who did just that in 1998 

Sunday 2 September 2001
Observer Sport Monthly 

It was the 1998 Australian Open and the Williams sisters, Venus and Serena, had seen some of the male players practising. On the basis of what they saw, they were convinced that they could beat a man ranked around 200 in the world and wanted to set up a game. At the time I was ranked 203 so the men's tour manager mentioned the possibility of a challenge to me, thinking that I was the perfect candidate. I didn't take much persuading, it seemed like a fun thing to do.

My advice if you're ever in a position to play a match of this nature is be patient - don't be annoyed or surprised if your match against the Williams sisters is cancelled, as they both have very busy schedules. My game against them had to be re-organised at least a couple of times.

Preparation is crucial. Remember that a game like this is light-hearted - taking it too seriously would be a mistake. My training regime consisted of a leisurely round of golf in the morning followed by a couple of shandies. I turned up on court feeling suitably laid-back.

My first game of the afternoon, just a one-set match, was against Serena. A hint: try and play your match somewhere quiet, where you're not going to be pestered by big crowds or lots of press - we were out on one of the back courts at Melbourne Park, No 17 I think it was. I felt so relaxed that I didn't even warm up properly. We started playing and I raced into a 5-0 lead.

At this point Venus turned up to watch. She had just finished a press conference after a quarter-final loss against Lindsey Davenport. In the end I won my game against Serena 6-1 but by the time we were at the net shaking hands, Venus was on court, ready to have a go against me as well. The game against Venus was very similar. I ended up winning 6-2.

Both sisters are great tennis players and hit the ball extremely well. However, if you've been playing on the men's tour there are certain shots you can play that are going to put them in difficulty. Try and put a lot spin on the ball - I was hitting the ball with a degree of spin they don't face week-in, week-out. Another key is to chase down every shot. In our match, they were putting shots into the corners that on the women's tour would be winners but I was able to return them.

In the end I won, but neither myself, nor Venus or Serena took the game too seriously - we were just having a bit of fun.

Apparently, after the game, Serena and Venus immediately told the press they wanted to challenge a male player again. This time they revised the ranking of the man they wanted to face, to 350 in the world. I informed the journalist who told me this that in the next week I was set to lose a lot of ATP points and drop down to 350 in the rankings. I told him that if Venus and Serena waited just one week they could challenge me all over again!

That never came about, but when I saw Venus a few months later at the French Open she came up to me with a big smile on her face and said, 'You know that thing in Australia - it never happened!'
